awd_titl_txt: Computational methods for nonribosomal peptide discovery
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Ribosomal Peptides (NRPs) represent a diverse class of natural products that include antibiotics, immunosuppressants, anticancer agents, toxins, siderophores, pigments, and cytostatics. NRPs have been reported in various habitats, from marine environments to soil, and even human microbiome. However, the discovery of novel NRPs remains a slow and laborious process because NRPs are not directly encoded in the genome and are instead assembled by Non-Ribosomal Peptide Synthetases (NRPSs). This project will develop computational techniques for discovering novel bioactive NRPs through the integration of computational mass spectrometry and genome mining. A summer pre-college program in computational biology and outreaching to under-represented students in Pittsburgh area through STEM junction symposiums will be carried out.

This project will develop algorithms for discovering novel bioactive NRPs through the following parts. First, the accuracy of prediction of adenylation domain (A-domain) substrate specificities will be improved through the incorporation of the 3-dimensional structure of domains. These features will be further used for identifying A-domains that encode novel chemistries in RefSeq microbial genomes. Second, algorithms will be developed for predicting the post-assembly modification of NRPs from the modification enzymes present in their gene cluster. Then, probabilistic models will be developed for matching predicted NRPs against mass spectra. These methods will be used to search the publicly available microbial genomes and mass spectra from RefSeq and global natural product social (GNPS) molecular networking infrastructure. The software and results of this project will be available to the scientific community through https://github.com/mohimanilab.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
During this project, we focused on two main objectives: predicting the product of  nonribosomal peptide biosynthetic gene cluster, and developing computational mass spectrometry methods to identify modifications involved in nonribosomal peptides.

To address the first objective, we have developed machine learning methods for prediction of the spcificity of adenylation domains. We trained these models on more than a thousand adenylation domain sequences with known specificity, and this significantly improved the accuracy of predictions. 

To address the second objective, we developed machine learning methods to predict how small molecules (including nonribosomal peptides) fragment in mass spectrometry. This model was trained hundreds of known small molecules and their mass spectra. Our benchmarks show that this model significantly improves the accuracy of tandem mass spectral database search. 

We used these methods to develope NPdiscover, a computational platform that integrated microbial genome mining with computational mass spectrometry for discovery of nonribosomal peptides. We tested this methods on publicly available datasets, and this led to discovery of various nonribosomal peptides, including Edaphochelin, an antifungal nonribosomal peptide that is bioactive against multidrug-resistant Candida pathogens. In vitro testings show that Edaphochelin has minimum inhibitory concentration of 0.5-2ug/ml agains variouns candida pathogens. In vivo testing shows that Edaphochelin is effective and safe in mice models.
